Ocean Module

The ocean module defines the ocean object, which loads physical characteristics and defines functions relevant to the emission by and reflection of microwave radiation by the ocean surface. The ocean module contains several different flavors of specular and wind-roughened ocean surface models.

The ocean.ocean base class returns a specular surface if mode='flat' and returns a wind-roughened surface approximation if mode='rough'. The wind-roughened model function is an interpolation of geophysical model functions developed by Remote Sensing Systems (Meissner and Wentz 2012, 2014). These model functions were developed at 1.4, 6.8, 10.7, 18.7, and 37 GHz from satellite microwave radiometer measurements, and they are extrapolated to lower frequencies assuming a zero intercept.

The ocean.fastem class implements the FASTEM-5 and FASTEM-6 ocean emissivity models developed by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (Liu et al 2011, Kazumori and English 2016), which are numerical approximations to a two-scale emissivity model. These model are applicable at frequencies from 1.4 to 410 GHz, and are preferred for high-frequency sensing.

The ocean.two_scale implements a full two-scale model emissivity model originally developed by Simon Yueh at JPL in his 1997 paper. The default ocean surface roughness spectrum is that of Durden and Vesecky, but several parameterizations are included from the work of Paul Hwang at the Naval Research Laboratory. This surface emissivity model is the most computationally expensive.

Development note: The current implementation of the two-scale model is relatively computationally inefficient, and its use is not recommended for large simulations. Future versions of the software should implement a revised two-scale model with improved performance

Ocean ancillary data sources are discussed in the utils.reader module documentation. The ocean object can also be specified using different dielectric constant modules, as discussed in the dielectric module.

Setting Up an Ocean object

ocean objects can be initialized using different ancillary data sources and dielectric constant modules, as discussed in the utils.reader and dielectric module documentation. An example initialization is shown below.

 1from foam.ocean import ocean
 2import foam.dielectric as dielectric
 3
 4# Pull data from online
 5oc = ocean(datetime='2015-01-01', mode='rough', online=True,
 6           sst_reader=reader.GHRSSTReader, sst_reader_kwargs={'version': 'MUR'},
 7           sss_reader=reader.OISSSReader, dielectric=dielectric.h2o_liquid_KleinSwift)
 8
 9# Use data from cache
10# or provide your own file using sst_file and sss_file
11oc = ocean(datetime='2018-01-01', mode='rough', online=False
12           dielectric=dielectric.h2o_liquid_Boutin)

After initializing an ocean object, you can compute ocean surface emissivity ocean.get_ocean_emissivity and brightness temperature ocean.get_ocean_TB

API

class foam.ocean.ocean(datetime='2015-01-01', mode='flat', online=False, sst_file=None, sst_reader=<class 'foam.utils.reader.GHRSSTReader'>, sst_reader_kwargs=None, sss_file=None, sss_reader=<class 'foam.utils.reader.OISSSReader'>, sss_reader_kwargs=None, dielectric=<function h2o_liquid_KleinSwift>, verbose=False, **kwargs)

Base class for generating an ocean forward model at a given state (temperature, salinity, surface winds)

Parameters

  • datetime – Either a single date or a pair of dates bracketing an interval of time. Several formats are permissible, such as - String or iterable of strings - Python datetime or iterable of datetimes - Numpy datetime64 or iterable - Pandas timestamp or iterable

  • mode – ‘flat’ mode implements a specular ocean surface ‘rough’ mode interpolates the Meissner/Wentz GMFs for wind-roughening

  • online – Toggles online functionality

  • sst_file – Sea surface temperature file location. Default is ‘cache’, which reads a stock file from the cache.

  • sss_file – Sea surface salinity file location. Default is ‘cache’, which reads a stock file from the cache.

  • sst_reader – File reader method, default is GHRSSTReader

  • sss_reader – File reader method, default is OISSSReader

  • verbose – Toggles verbosity

Note that only one file per parameter is downloaded in the cache.

For plotting convenience, arrays with geographic info are defined as they would appear on a map, rows of decreasing latitude (90 -> -90) and columns of increasing longitude (-180 -> 180)

read_ocean()

Reads ocean state from online or local files. Sets up RegularGridInterpolators which take arguments of lat and lon.

read_land()

Reads EASE2 Grid 3 km landmask file. Sets up a RegularGridInterpolator which takes arguments of lat and lon.

get_ocean_TB(frequency, time, lat, lon, uwind, vwind, theta, phi, in_epoch=False, use_time=True)

Calculates emission temperature of the ocean from frequency, emission angle, and meshgrids of latitude and longitude. Type of all inputs should be numpy arrays

Parameters

  • frequency – Frequency in MHz (dimension M)

  • time – String or array of times, converted to interpolator epoch reference if in_epoch=False

  • lat – Latitude in diegrees

  • lon – Longitude in degrees

  • uwind – E/W 10-m wind

  • vwind – N/S 10-m wind

  • theta – Elevation angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

  • phi – Azimuth angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

  • in_epoch – See above

  • use_time – Allows for bypass of time resolution in the case of heterogeneous time sources

Returns

Full Stokes brightness temperatures and emissivity (dimension 4xMx…)

get_ocean_emissivity(frequency, sst, sss, uwind, vwind, theta, phi)

Returns ocean emissivity. This is the specular surface emissivity if ocean.mode is ‘simple’, and GMF wind-roughened emissivity if ocean.mode is ‘full’

Parameters

  • frequency – Frequency in MHz

  • sst – Sea surface temperature in Kelvin

  • sss – Sea surface salinity in psu

  • uwind – 10-m eastward wind in m/s

  • vwind – 10-m northward wind in m/s

  • theta – Elevation angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

  • phi – Azimuth angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

Returns

Emissivity vector (eV, eH, U, V) (dimension 4x…)

get_roughness_correction(frequency, sst, sss, uwind, vwind, theta, phi)

Returns only excess emissivity due to wind roughening

Parameters

  • frequency – Frequency in MHz

  • sst – Sea surface temperature in Kelvin

  • sss – Sea surface salinity in psu

  • uwind – 10-m eastward wind in m/s

  • vwind – 10-m northward wind in m/s

  • theta – Elevation angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

  • phi – Azimuth angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

Returns

Excess emissivity vector (eV, eH, U, V) (dimension 4x…)

class foam.ocean.fastem(version='6', **kwargs)

FASTEM ocean emissivity models from 1.4 - 410 GHz. Developed by ECMWF and translated to Python.

Parameters

version – Either ‘5’ or ‘6’ (default). See Kazumori and English 2015 for differences

read_ocean()

Reads ocean state from online or local files. Sets up RegularGridInterpolators which take arguments of lat and lon.

get_ocean_emissivity(frequency, sst, sss, uwind, vwind, theta, phi)

FASTEM emissivity models

Parameters

  • frequency – Frequency in MHz (dimension O)

  • sst – Sea surface temperature in Kelvin (dimension MxN)

  • sss – Sea surface salinity in psu (dimension MxN)

  • uwind – 10-m eastward wind in m/s

  • vwind – 10-m northward wind in m/s

  • theta – Elevation angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

  • phi – Azimuth angle of spacecraft with respect to surface normal

Return emis

Emissivity vector (eV, eH, U, V) (dimension 4xOxMxN)

class foam.ocean.two_scale(spectrum='Durden-Vesecky', **kwargs)

Implements two-scale ocean surface model and associated reflections

Development note: The current implementation of the two-scale model is relatively computationally inefficient, and its use is not recommended for large simulations. Future versions of the software should implement a revised two-scale model with improved performance

Parameters

spectrum –

Specifies isotropic ocean spectrum model. Options are: ‘Durden-Vesecky’, ‘Pierson-Moskowitz’,

’JONSWAP’, ‘Donelan’, or ‘General’

Several modules are translated from Simon Yueh’s original two-scale code in Fortran

get_ocean_emissivity(frequency, sst, sss, uwind, vwind, theta, phi, cutoff_factor=3, parallel=False, nproc=4, Ns=4)

Calculates emissivity for a wind-roughened ocean surface using a two-scale model

Parameters

  • frequency – Frequency in MHz (dimension O)

  • sst – Sea surface temperature in Kelvin (dimension MxN)

  • sss – Sea surface salinity in psu (dimension MxN)

  • uwind – 10-m eastward wind in m/s (dimension MxN)

  • vwind – 10-m northward wind in m/s (dimension MxN)

  • theta – Topocentric elevation angle in degrees

  • phi – Topocentric azimuth angle in degrees

  • cutoff_factor – Changes the scale cutoff wavelength. Default is 3 (e.g. k0/3 is the cutoff). See Yueh et al. 1997

  • parallel – If True, compute in parallel (default False)

  • nproc – Number of parallel processes (default 4)

  • Ns – Extent of the integrals (Ns * std. dev. of the distribution)

Return emisV, emisH, U, V

Stokes vector emissivity (dimension (OxMxN))

foam.ocean.speed_10m_to_friction(wind, method='hwang')

Converts 10m-winds to wind friction

‘yueh’ method is a polynomial fit to an iterative calculation procedure written by Simon Yueh, and the ‘hwang’ method implements Paul Hwang’s drag coefficient for 10-m winds

Parameters

  • wind – 10-meter wind speed in m/s (must be an array)

  • method – Calculation method of ‘hwang’ or ‘yueh’

foam.ocean.friction_to_speed(friction, z)

Convert wind friction to velocity using formula from Yueh 1997 :param friction: Wind friction :param z: Height of output wind speed

foam.ocean.spectrum_PM(k, wind)

Isotropic surface spectrum of Pierson and Moskowitz 1964

Parameters

  • k – Ocean wavenumber (rad/m)

  • wind – 10-m wind speed (m/s)

Returns

Wavenumber spectrum in m^3

foam.ocean.spectrum_DV(k, wind)

Isotropic surface spectrum of Durden and Vesecky 1985

Parameters

  • k – Ocean wavenumber (rad/m)

  • wind – 10-m wind speed (m/s)

Returns

Wavenumber spectrum in m^3

foam.ocean.spectrum_jonswap(k, wind)

Isotropic surface spectrum derived from JONSWAP measurements

Fetch term removed by setting the center frequency equal to the PM spectrum for a fully developed ocean surface

Parameters

  • k – Ocean wavenumber (rad/m)

  • wind – 10-m wind speed (m/s)

Returns

Wavenumber spectrum in m^3

foam.ocean.spectrum_donelan(k, wind)

Isotropic surface spectrum of Donelan et al. 1985

Fetch term removed by setting the center frequency equal to the PM spectrum for a fully developed ocean surface

Parameters

  • k – Ocean wavenumber (rad/m)

  • wind – 10-m wind speed (m/s)

Returns

Wavenumber spectrum in m^3

foam.ocean.spectrum_general(k, wind, s_g=4.5, beta_g=4)

Isotropic general model surface spectrum from Hwang 2017

Parameters

  • k – Ocean wavenumber (rad/m)

  • wind – 10-m wind speed (m/s)

  • s_g – Variable

Returns

Wavenumber spectrum in m^3

foam.ocean.get_spectrum(k, phi, wind, c=None, model='Durden-Vesecky')

Returns direction dependent ocean spectrum Choice of isotropic spectrum specified by model See Yueh 1997

Parameters

  • k – Ocean wavenumber in 1/m

  • phi – Look angle azimuth in radians

  • wind – 10-m wind in m/s

  • c – C parameter for directional spectrum costly to compute, so provided as an arg

  • model –

    Isotropic spectrum model Options are: ‘Durden-Vesecky’ (default)

    ’Pierson-Moskowitz’ ‘JONSWAP’ ‘Donelan’ ‘General’

foam.ocean.slope_to_normal(psix, psiy)

Used to calculate the direction of the surface normal given the slope angle.

param psix

angle of the slope in x for the local plane

param psiy

angle of the slope in y for the local plane

return

thetan - zenith angle of surface normal phin - azimuth angle of surface normal

foam.ocean.pdf_slope(Su2, Sc2, Zx, Zy)

Returns the pdf of the slope of the large scale surface which is assumed to be Gaussian. This PDF was used by S. Durden for his two scale theory for a large scale surface.

Parameters

  • Su2 – Slope variance in x (up-wind)

  • Sc2 – Slope variance in y (cross-wind)

  • Zx – Slope in x (up-wind)

  • Zy – Slope in y (cross-wind)

Returns

Slope PDF

foam.ocean.cox_munk_variance(wind)

Slope variance expressions of Cox and Munk

Parameters

wind – 10-m wind speed

Returns

Su2 - Slope variance in up wind direction Sc2 - Slope variance in cross wind direction

foam.ocean.slope_variance(kd, wind, c, model='Durden-Vesecky')

Used to numerically calculate the variances of the large scale surface with a given cutoff frequency.

Parameters

  • kd – high frequency cutoff for the large scale wave

  • wind – 10-m wind speed

Returns

Su2 - Slope variance in up wind direction Sc2 - Slope variance in cross wind direction

foam.ocean.angle_pol_trans(theta, phi, psix, psiy)

This routine is used to covert the incident direction in principal frame to local frame.

Parameters

  • theta – zenith angle

  • phi – polar angle

  • psix – angle of the slope in x for the local plane

  • psiy – angle of the slope in y for the local plane

Returns

thetal - local zenith angle

phil - local azimuth angle

hh - vector product of h pol. vector and h’’ pol. vector

hv - vector product of h pol. vector and v’’ pol. vector

foam.ocean.foam_fraction(wind)

Foam parameterization from Hwang 2012

Parameters

wind – 10-m wind speed (m/s)

Returns

Foam fraction for that wind speed

foam.ocean.R_coherent(thetai, phii, eps, wind, k0, kd, c=None, model='Durden-Vesecky')

Computes the coherent reflectivity coefficients for Bragg scattering using the small perturbation method.

Parameters

  • thetai – Incident elevation angle

  • phii – Incident azimuth angle

  • eps – Surface dielectric constant

  • k0 – Electromagnetic wavenumber

  • wind – 10-m wind speed

Returns

Rh0, Rv0 - Specular reflectivities for H and V pol

shh, svh, svv, shv - Second order coherent reflection co-pol and cross-pol terms

foam.ocean.R_incoherent(thetal, phil, eps, wind, k0, kd, c=None, model='Durden-Vesecky')

Computes the incoherent reflectivity from a slightly perturbed Gaussian random rough surface with ocean spectrum.

Parameters

  • thetal – local observing polar angle

  • phil – local observing azimuth angle

  • eps – permittivity of lower half space medium

  • k0 – free space electromagnetic wavenumber

  • wind – 10m wind speed

Returns

Rx - Incoherent reflectivity
